DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said he hopes a trade deal with China can be finalised in two more rounds and the enforcement mechanism is close to done. In related news, there were also comments from NEC Director Kudlow that he is cautiously optimistic on US/China trade deal and next 2 weeks should give clarity on the status of the talks, while he suggested the sides were "pretty close" to a deal. (Newswires/Fox Business News)

 

UK/EU

UK PM May spokesman said a way forward in cross-party talks with Labour has yet to be found and that the government would like to introduce a Withdrawal Agreement bill ASAP but needs assurance that it will pass in Parliament. In related news, there were later reports that sources from both sides hinted of a new optimism in discussions and that discussions have moved on to the “nuts and bolts” of a potential compromise. (Newswires/Guardian)

UK opposition Labour party leader Corbyn was warned that a refusal to commit to a fresh Brexit referendum could cause Labour members to abandon the party in their droves, as its ruling body prepares to meet to decide the party's manifesto for the European elections. In separate reports, Labour could put in its manifesto that there could be a second referendum or confirmatory referendum on any Brexit deal proposed by the government, according to ITV's Peston. (Independent /Twitter)

S&P said severe downgrade of Italy is unlikely and that an early election would not necessarily be a negative. (Newswires)

  • EU Business Climate (Apr) 0.42 vs. Exp. 0.49 (Prev. 0.53, Rev. 0.54). (Newswires)
  • EU Consumer Confidence (Apr) -7.9 vs. Exp. -7.9 (Prev. -7.9, Rev. -7.2)
  • EU Economic Sentiment (Apr) 104.0 vs. Exp. 105.0 (Prev. 105.5, Rev. 105.6)
  • EU Industrial Sentiment (Apr) -4.1 vs. Exp. -2.0 (Prev. -1.7, Rev. -1.6)
  • EU Services Sentiment (Apr) 11.5 vs. Exp. 11.2 (Prev. 11.3, Rev. 11.5)

 

US

NEC Director Kudlow said slowing inflation opens the door for possible rate cuts and that the White House still backs Stephen Moore for Fed Board role. Kudlow also commented that USMCA is in good shape for passage and that the US has massive infrastructure needs which must be met with "substantial, real and new revenue". (Newswires)

US Core PCE Price Index (Mar) Y/Y 1.6% vs. Exp. 1.7% (Prev. 1.8%). (Newswires)

Alphabet Inc (GOOG) Q1 EPS Ex-fine USD 11.90 vs. Exp. USD 10.51, rev. USD 36.1bln vs. Exp. 39.07bln. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

Intel (INTC) moved lower after being downgraded to hold from buy at Argus. Tesla (TSLA) moved higher throughout the session, shrugging off reports that bankers were becoming increasingly concerned over the automaker’s finances, as markets digested the news of CEO Musk coming to an agreement with the SEC, where his tweeting of sensitive information will be vetted. PayPal (PYPL) rose throughout the session with reports that the payments technology co. would make a USD 500mln investment in Uber as part of the ride-hailing co’s upcoming IPO. Archer Daniel’s Midland (ADM) shares rose after BMO lifted its rating to outperform. American Airlines (AAL) shares were buoyed after the airline was upgraded to buy at Deutsche Bank. Adobe (ADBE) shares moved higher on the back of a broker upgrade from Morgan Stanley. NXP (NXPI) Occidental (OXY) fell after Anadarko (APC) stated its intent to resume talks with the energy co, as their offer could be ‘superior’ to Chevron’s (CVX), but added that the Chevron deal remains intact for now. Anadarko traded mixed but ultimately finished higher, as did Chevron. Disney (DIS) traded lower despite key franchise Avengers setting box office records at the weekend. Take Two (TTWO) shares caught a bid after Stephens added the video game maker to its Best Idea list and raised their profit target by USD 10 whilst dropping EA (EA) as a sector best idea. Financials names (JPM, GS, BAC, WFC, MS) outperformed, with analysts citing the US curve bear-steepening. SPX +0.1% at 2943, NDX +0.2% at 7839, DJI +0.0% at 26554.

The US Treasury curve bear-steepened on Monday, ahead of key event risk in the week (including FOMC, NFP, ISM, as well as key data on the other side of the Atlantic). While the M/M Personal Spending data came in ahead of expectations, the PCE components - the Fed's preferred gauge - disappointed, and has softened for the third straight month going into Wednesday's FOMC. Meanwhile, the US Treasury has cut its borrowing estimate for Q2, and now expects to issue USD 30bln in net marketable debt in Q2 (prev. estimate was USD 83bln), and also says it expects to issue 160bln in net marketable debt in Q3. It borrowed USD 374bln in Q1. Overnight China PMIs will be looked at for further stabilisation out of the world's second largest economy, while EZ Q1 advanced data will be the focus in early trade. US T-note futures (M9) settled 7+ ticks lower at 123-14.

US MARKET WRAP 26 April 2019: SPX hits record highs ahead of this week’s key event risk
content:
* SNAP SHOT: Equities up, dollar down, Treasuries down, crude mixed.

* REAR VIEW: S&P500 hits all time intra-day highs, US Core PCE Data soft

* COMING UP: US Employment Cost Index (Q1), US Pending Home Sales (Mar), US CB Consumer Confidence (Apr), CA GDP (Feb), BOC Poloz/Wilkins:, EZ GDP (Q1/A), EZ Unemployment (Mar), Ger Unemployment (Apr), Ger CPI (Apr/P), Ger 2021 Auction, UK BRC (Apr), BOE Ramsden, CH KOF (Apr), AU MFG PMI (Apr/F), Ch MFG PMI (Apr),  Ru MFG PMI (Apr), Nor Retail Sales (Mar), NZ Unemployment (Q1), HU PPI (Mar), Tur Trade Balance (Mar), PD CPI (Apr), Za Trade Balance (Mar), Mex GDP (Q1/P).

* TUESDAY’S EARNINGS: AAPL, AMD; MA; PFE, MRK, LLY; MCD; MDLZ, KHC; AMGN, CHTR; GE; COP, PSX; GM

* US PERSONAL INCOME & SPENDING: US Personal Income and Spending: Personal income +0.1% MM (exp. +0.4%), spending +0.9% M/M (exp. +0.7%), real spending +0.7% (exp. 0.5%). Y/Y PCE was short of consensus at 1.6% (exp. 1.7%); Pantheon says this will not have gone unnoticed at the Fed; the consultancy thinks it is most likely noise than it is a signal, "but the Y/Y rate is unlikely to rise much before late summer and could easily dip further in the meantime," and "if the Fed hikes this year, it will be because of accelerating wages, not the inflation rate at the time."

* FED PREVIEW: FOMC to leave rates unchanged on 1 May (decision due 1900 BST/1400 EDT, ahead of the press conference with Chair Powell at 1930 BST/1430 EDT); The Fed will not publish new economic projections at this meeting (SEP next released in June). The market will be watching whether the Fed outlines conditions that might compel the Committee to discuss lowering rates. There are some risks that the Fed might tweak its statement to reflect stronger growth and softer inflation since the last meeting. There is also a possibility the Fed could lower its IOER rate. The Committee’s tone is likely to remain one of patience and data dependence. To download the report, please click here.

* US/CHINA TRADE TALKS: US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said that the US is approaching the final laps of trade talks. NEC Director Kudlow weighed in, reiterating his ‘cautious’ optimism that a deal would agree upon and that the next two weeks should give clarity on the status of the talks. Elsewhere, trade talks are being conducted in their respective dialects, and a text of the agreement between the two sides will be published in both Chinese and English, SCMP reports. Lawyers will then parse through both texts in an effort to reach a final draft both sides are happy with, though analysts note that this can often prove to be very tricky. The US, however, is keen to avoid the uncertainties, since it seeks a unilateral mechanism to determine if China is abiding by the terms of any agreement.

* WTI (K9) SETTLES USD 0.20 HIGHER AT USD /BBL; BRENT (M9) SETTLES USD LOWER AT USD /BBL. Crude markets are consolidating (WTI above USD 63.00and Brent above USD 72) as Russia resumes exports of Urals on the Druzhba pipeline, after an outage due to contamination issues last week.  "Friday’s price drop and last week’s increase in US commercial crude oil inventories to the highest level since November 2017 have dampened bullish sentiment for now, but full imposition of US sanctions on Iranian crude oil exports and the broader worry over declining OPEC+ total supply remains supportive," Citi said, and the bank suggests that market may also be seeing some book squaring as June Brent, May heating oil, and May RBOB gasoline futures all expire on Tuesday. In news, an Iranian official said US sanctions will destabilise global oil markets; the Chief commander of Iran's Quds force has argued that talks with US are impossible. In Iraq, southern oil exports is averaging 3.33mln BPD in April mtd (vs 3.25mln BPD in March). In Nigeria, Shell declared a force majeure on exports of Bonny Light after a pipeline closure.

* SPX +0.1% at 2943, NDX +0.2% at 7839, DJI +0.0% at 26554. SECTORS: Communications +0.3%, Cons Discretionary -0.4%, Cons Staples +0.1%, Energy -0.3%, Financials +0.9%, Healthcare -0.2%, Industrials +0.3%, Materials -0.2%, Tech -0.0%, Telecoms +0.9%, Utilities -0.6%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Intel (INTC) moved lower after being downgraded to hold from buy at Argus. Tesla (TSLA) moved higher throughout the session, shrugging off reports that bankers were becoming increasingly concerned over the automaker’s finances, as markets digested the news of CEO Musk coming to an agreement with the SEC, where his tweeting of sensitive information will be vetted. PayPal (PYPL) rose throughout the session with reports that the payments technology co. would make a USD 500mln investment in Uber as part of the ride-hailing co’s upcoming IPO. Archer Daniel’s Midland (ADM) shares rose after BMO lifted its rating to outperform. American Airlines (AAL) shares were buoyed after the airline was upgraded to buy at Deutsche Bank. Adobe (ADBE) shares moved higher on the back of a broker upgrade from Morgan Stanley. NXP (NXPI) Occidental (OXY) fell after Anadarko (APC) stated its intent to resume talks with the energy co, as their offer could be ‘superior’ to Chevron’s (CVX), but added that the Chevron deal remains intact for now. Anadarko traded mixed but ultimately finished higher, as did Chevron. Disney (DIS) traded lower despite key franchise Avengers setting box office records at the weekend. Take Two (TTWO) shares caught a bid after Stephens added the video game maker to its Best Idea list and raised their profit target by USD 10 whilst dropping EA (EA) as a sector best idea. Financials names (JPM, GS, BAC, WFC, MS) outperformed, with analysts citing the US curve bear-steepening.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLE 7+ TICKS LOWER 123-14 AT. The US Treasury curve bear-steepened on Monday, ahead of key event risk in the week (including FOMC, NFP, ISM, as well as key data on the other side of the Atlantic). While the M/M Personal Spending data came in ahead of expectations, the PCE components - the Fed's preferred gauge - disappointed, and has softened for the third straight month going into Wednesday's FOMC. Meanwhile, the US Treasury has cut its borrowing estimate for Q2, and now expects to issue USD 30bln in net marketable debt in Q2 (prev. estimate was USD 83bln), and also says it expects to issue 160bln in net marketable debt in Q3. It borrowed USD 374bln in Q1. Overnight China PMIs will be looked at for further stabilisation out of the world's second largest economy, while EZ Q1 advanced data will be the focus in early trade. 

* FX WRAP: USD; DXY was unable to hold above the 98.00 handle as core PCE figures came in below expectations, raising the bar for Fed hawkishness at the policy meeting this week. EUR edged higher on the day, largely shrugging off underwhelming sentiment data, with desks citing eurozone relief regarding a lack of surprises in the Spanish elections and Italy avoiding a downgrade. GBP, having regained the 1.2900 handle, traded relatively flat and was unresponsive to source reports that May could be ousted in June, the markets awaiting the outcome of cross-party talks, of which the tone was reportedly better on Monday. JPY weaken slightly amid growing risk appetite (as SPX hit fresh all-time highs and the curve bear steepened) but JPY traded with thin liquidity, with the Japanese on holiday for Golden Week. CAD traded mixed ahead of tomorrow’s (Feb) GDP data release. AUD/NZD strengthened against the USD, buoyed by a rebound in Chinese industrial profits in March and positive news flow regarding US/China trade talks, with talks reportedly in the ‘last stretch’.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Relatively tentative trade ahead of pending risk events
content:
DXY:

Poised to end the EU session around 98.000, having pivoted on either side of the level throughout the session. The USD was little changed following optimistic US-Sino comments from Treasury Secretary Mnuchin, although, overall subdued core PCE figures briefly dented the index, albeit DXY nursed those marginal losses and stays afloat above 98.000. It’s worth noting that due to SOMA tomorrow, USD liquidity will shrink by USD 28.1bln. Meanwhile, looking at FX month-end rebalancing, Citi’s model sees marginal USD selling whilst Barclay’s model suggests strong USD selling vs. major peers. Nonetheless, USD is set to end EU trade flat with nothing scheduled of note left on the docket.

AUD, NZD, EUR:

The Aussie and Kiwi remain the most resilient against the Greenback, underpinned by an improvement in Chinese industrial profits and latest US-China trade reports suggesting negotiations are reaching the last stretch. NZD/USD remains just about afloat above 0.6650 (for now), albeit closer to the bottom of a 0.6650-80 band, whilst its Aussie counterpart similarly pared most of the day’s gains and is poised to end EU trade below 0.7050 having fluctuated in a 0.7037-60 range. Finally, the single currency largely shrugged off the mostly weaker than forecast Eurozone sentiment indicators which were countered by a degree of relief post-Spanish election and S&P reaffirming Italy’s BBB rating. EUR/USD looks set to end EU trade around 1.1150 after having recently found support around 1.1100.

GBP:

Choppy trade for the Pound, but largely set to end little changed vs. the Buck, albeit above 1.2900, with Brexit talks still seemingly dead-locked with PM May’s spokesman reaffirming that a way forward in cross-party talks with Labour has yet to be found, whilst sources over the weekend noted that PM May will be ousted by end-June if cross-party talks crumble.

JPY, CAD:

All slightly weaker against the Dollar, with JPY as the main G10 laggard having marginally extended today’s parameter to 111.54-84 with upside in the pair possible aided by the risk-appetite as the E-mini S&P prints new all-time highs, although it’s worth keeping in mind the absence of Japanese markets (until May 7th) due to the Golden Week holidays. Levels to the downside for the pair include its 200 DMA at 111.51, strong chart support sub-111.50 as the 30 DMA, 38.2% Fib retracement of April peak to March trough (112.40-109.70) and last week’s low all fall at 111.37. Meanwhile the Loonie remains vulnerable to oil price action and thus USD/CAD is poised to end the session closer to the top of an 1.3450-1.3480 range.

subject: PREVIEW: FOMC May 2019; decision due 1 May 2019 at 1900 BST/1400 EDT
content:
• FOMC to leave rates unchanged on 1 May (decision due 1900 BST/1400 EDT, ahead of the press conference with Chair Powell at 1930 BST/1430 EDT); The Fed will not publish new economic projections at this meeting (SEP next released in June). The market will be watching whether the Fed outlines conditions that might compel the Committee to discuss lowering rates. There are some risks that the Fed might tweak its statement to reflect stronger growth and softer inflation since the last meeting. There is also a possibility the Fed could lower its IOER rate. The Committee’s tone is likely to remain one of patience and data dependence. To download the report, please click here

Fixed and FX latest: muted reaction to mild US core PCE
content: Perhaps forewarned is forearmed as weaker than expected US core PCE metrics for the month of March only prompted a knee-jerk response in bond and currency markets following hot on the heels of Q1 data last Friday. Moreover, although income was even lower vs consensus, a beat on consumption may have offset the benign pre-FOMC inflation update. Hence, bonds are back under pressure and the DXY has actually nudged up to a fresh, albeit marginal new session peak at 98.111 after a brief dip through the round number.

subject: DAILY US EQUITY OPENING NEWS - BA, DIS, APC, OXY, CVX, BRK.B, MA, V, TSLA
content:
DOW

  • Boeing (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defence) 737 MAX may be cleared by FAA in late May or June, according to the Seattle Times, citing sources familiar with the deliberations. This would come much more quickly than many analysts have predicted, though the pilots would have to be trained on the new systems, which may put the effective resumption of operations by most airlines sometime in August. Separately, WSJ reports that Boeing did not tell its largest 737 MAX customer Southwest (LUV) that safety features designed to warn over malfunctioning sensors were deactivated when LUV began flying 737s in 2017. Elsewhere, Emirates is looking at a possible Airbus (AIR FP) if Max orders cannot be fulfilled. FAA will take up new air worthiness directive for Boeing (BA) 737 Max, citing leakage. Finally, the co. forecasts a need for 43k new commercial aircraft in the next twenty years.
  • Disney (DIS) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) ‘Avengers: Endgame’ smashes weekend box office records in a USD 1.2bln launch. Analysts are encouraged ahead of Disney’s release of The Lion King, Toy Story 4 over the coming months.
  • Microsoft (MSFT) (Information Technology/Systems Software) PT raised at Argus to USD 145 from USD 128.

S&P 500

  • Anadarko (APC), Occidental (OXY), Chevron (CVX) (Energy/O&G E&P) APC stated it intends to resume talks with Occidental (OXY) as it could result in "a superior deal", adding that the Chevron (CVX) merger pact remains intact and their board affirms their recommendation for the Chevron deal at this point.
  • Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.B) (Financials/Multi Sector Holdings) Co reports Friday, and Barron’s says CEO Buffet will face tough questions about its lagging share price at the shareholder meeting on 4 May. Key will be what the company intends to do with its USD 110bln of cash; Buffet has already ruled out a dividend. Barron’s noted that Berkshire still looks appealing on earnings, book value, and outlook.
  • DaVita (DVA) (Health Care/Health Care Facilities) Co names Javier Rodriguez as new CEO, effective 1 June.
  • Ebay (EBAY) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet retail) CFO on 25 April sold 89.7k shares at USD 38.50/shr (totalling USD 3.45mln), according to a filing.
  • Edwards Lifesciences (EW) (Health Care/Health Care Equipment) recalls certain lots of its Miller Balloon Atrioseptostomy Catheters, and Fogarty Dilation Atrioseptostomy Dilation Catheters, due to safety risks.
  • ETRADE (ETFC) (Financials/IB & Brokerage) intends to offer cryptocurrency trading on its platform, sources report, to compete with Coinbase and Robinhood.
  • Ingersoll-Rand (IR) (Industrials/Industrial Machinery) – Gardner Denver Holdings (GDI) nearing deal to merge with a division of Ingersoll-Rand (IR), would create a business with an enterprise value of around USD 15bln, WSJ reported, saying that a deal could be announced this week. IR would own half of the new company which would be structured in with cash and stock for holders. 
  • Lennar (LEN) (Consumer Discretionary/Homebuilding) announced it has closed a lot purchase agreement with Level Homes; LEN will now control an additional 1,602 new homesites across seven communities throughout the Raleigh market.
  • Lockheed Martin (LMT) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defence) The defence contractor announces successful completion of AEHF-4 spacecraft on orbit test, which successfully activated its payload made by subcontractor Northrup Grumman (NOC).
  • Mastercard (MA) and Visa (V) (Information Technology/IT Services) The EU has accepted an offer by both companies to cut fees on payments made by tourists using cards issued outside the bloc, in order to avoid fines and end an EU antitrust probe.
  • Parker-Hannifin (PH) (Industrials/Industrial Machinery) to acquire LORD Corporation for around USD 3.68bln in cash.
  • Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD) (Energy/O&G E&P) in advanced talks to sell Eagle Ford acreage in South Texas to privately held Ensign Natural Resources. If the sale goes through, it would achieve PXD’s aim of being solely focussed on the Permian region.
  • SNAP Inc (SNAP) The Co. and Spotify (SPOT) announce a new partnership that will let small businesses that sell on Shopify buy ads, CNBC reports.

NASDAQ 100

  • Amazon.com (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing) After AMZN announced its Prime members will get orders within a day, Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, which is attempting to unionise AMZN workers, said workers are already struggling to handle orders with the promise of two-day shipping.
  • Costco (COST) (Consumer Staples/Hypermarkets) announces USD 4bln share buy-back, replacing the current USD 4bln which had an unused authorisation of USD 2.2bln. Costco also raised quarterly dividend by 8c to USD 0.65/shr.
  • Qualcomm (QCOM) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) the chipmaker had their price target raised to USD 90 (prev. USD 60) at Deutsche Bank.
  • Regeneron (REGN) (Health Care/Biotechnology) US FDA approves RGN’s cholesterol drug in the treatment of heart attacks, strokes, and other cardiovascular events.
  • Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) CEO Elon Musk has agreed a deal with the SEC, settling a dispute over his use of Twitter. If the deal is approved by a judge, Musk will not face being held in contempt of court. Additionally, the automaker announced that Q1 restructuring efforts would result in USD 180mln savings in FY19, that cash generated by core activities should be sufficient to cover future capital expenditures and near-term debt obligations, but it may seek alternative financing; it also said that it would increase Model 3 production rate to 7k per week by end 2019.

OTHER

  • Energy Names (PSX, HFC, PBF, MPC, VLO) BofA/Merrill Lynch analyst says the worst has passed for the US independent refiners, and is now less cautious on the sector, upgrading HollyFrontier (HFC) and PBF Energy (PBF) to Neutral, raises Phillips66 (PSX) to Buy, says top-rated ideas in the sector remain Marathon Petrol (MPC) and Valero (VLO).
  • Gaming Names (TTWO, EA, ATVI) Stephens add Take-Two (TTWO) to Best Idea list, raise PT by USD 10 to USD 120. EA dropped as sector best idea.
  • Restaurant Brands (QSR) (Consumer Cyclicals/Restaurants) (USD) Q1 adj EPS 0.55 (exp. 0.56), revenue 1.27bln (exp. 1.15bln), Tim Horton SSS -0.6%, Burger King SSS +2.2%, Popeye’s SSS +0.6%
  • Spotify (SPOT) (Information Technology/Internet) (EUR) Q1 EPS -0.79 (vs -1.01 a year ago), MAUs rise 26% Y/Y to 217mln (exp. 215-220mln). Guides Q MAU between 222-228mln (+23-27% Y/Y(, sees subscribers between 107-110mln in Q2 (+29-34% Y/Y).
  • Toyota (TM) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) – US President Trump announced that Japan would invest USD 40bln in US factories. In other news, the automaker announced on Friday that it would suspend plans to include Dedicated Short-Range Communications (DSRC) technology, which allows communication between vehicles to avoid collisions, in its US vehicles.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 29th April 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European indices have continued to edge lower after a choppy morning for stocks [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.5%]
  • On the trade front, US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin says that trade negotiations with China are now in their final laps
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Personal Income & Consumption, US PCE Price Index & Dallas Fed
  • Earnings: Alphabet, NXP Semiconductor

ASIA-PAC

Asian equities traded mixed despite last Friday’s gains on Wall St where sensational Q1 GDP and soft Core PCE Prices suggested a Goldilocks economy and propelled US stock markets to fresh record closes, as this week’s looming risk events and holiday closures restricted upside for the region. ASX 200 (-0.4%) was the laggard amid losses in its largest-weighted financials sector and with energy names also downbeat after a pullback in oil prices, while this week’s array of key releases including Chinese PMI, US NFP, BoE and FOMC announcements also added to the tentative tone. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.9%) was positive after data showed Chinese Industrial Profits recovered in March and with focus on earnings including Agricultural Bank of China which kicked off the Big 4 bank earnings with an improvement in Q1 net, while Shanghai Comp. (-0.7%) was less decisive after the PBoC refrained from liquidity operations and with the mainland only open for the first 2 days of this week. As a reminder, Japan is closed until May 7th.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7310 (Prev. 6.7307)

Agricultural Bank of China (1288 HK) - Co. Q1 net CNY 61.3bln vs. Prev. CNY 58.7bln Y/Y. Co. closed higher by around 0.8% (Newswires)

ICBC (1398 HK) - Q1 net profit CNY 82.01bln vs. Prev. CNY 78.8bln, net interest income CNY 148bln vs. Prev. CNY 137bln, capital adequacy ratio at end-March at 12.84%. (Newswires)

Bank of China (3988 HK) - Q1 net profit CNY 50.97bln vs. Exp. CNY 49bln, NPL Ratio 1.42% vs. Prev. 1.42%, net interest margin 1.82% vs. Prev. 1.90%, CET1 Ratio 11.38% vs. Prev. 11.41%. (Newswires)

Chinese Industrial Profits (Mar) Y/Y 13.9% (Prev. -14.0%). (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said trade negotiations with China are in the final laps. (NYT)

UK/EU

UK opposition Labour Party accused the government of refusing to compromise on its red lines in cross-party talks. (Sky News)

Labour is said to be prepared to sign up to a Brexit deal with the government without the promise of a referendum attached if cross-party talks make significant progress in the coming days according to one of the party’s negotiators, while it was separately reported that Labour deputy leader Watson stepped up calls for his party to promise a referendum on any Brexit deal in its European elections manifesto. (Guardian/BBC)

Subsequently, UK PM May spokesman says a way forward in cross-party talks with Labour has yet to be found, would like to introduce a Withdrawal Agreement bill ASAP, but needs assurance that it will pass in Parliament. (Newswires)

Sources stated that PM May could be axed as PM by the end of June if cross-party talks with Labour break down. (The Sun)

The Conservative party can expect to lose 800 or more seats at this week’s local elections according to a leading Tory analyst. (Guardian)

Spain’s election over the weekend showed no party won a majority but the incumbent Socialists under PM Sanchez emerged as the only party with a chance of forming a governing coalition with 123 out of the 350 seats in parliament, while conservatives won 65 seats, centre right at 57 seats and far fright at 24 seats. (Newswires) Subsequently, Spain’s Socialist Party are in no rush to form a government, according to the Party Head. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed UK at AA; Outlook Negative and affirmed Netherlands at AAA; Outlook Stable, while S&P affirmed UK at AA; Outlook Negative and affirmed Italy at BBB; Outlook Negative. (Newswires)

EU Consumer Confidence Final (Apr) -7.9 vs. Exp. -7.9 (Prev. -7.9, Rev. -7.2) (Newswires)

- EU Industrial Sentiment (Apr) -4.1 vs. Exp. -2.0 (Prev. -1.7, Rev. -1.6)

- EU Services Sentiment (Apr) 11.5 vs. Exp. 11.1 (Prev. 11.3, Rev. 11.5)

- EU Economic Sentiment (Apr) 104.0 vs. Exp. 105.0 (Prev. 105.5, Rev. 105.6)

Italian Producer Prices YY* (Mar) 2.9% (Prev. 3.1%). (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Major European indices are choppy but overall marginally lower [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.5%], following on from their Asian counterparts ahead of a week with multiple market closures and several key risk events. Sectors are similarly mixed, with some mild underperformance seen in energy names in-line with the complex in general. The IBEX 35 (-0.4%) is lagging its peers this morning following on from the Spanish elections where the incumbent Socialist party emerged as the only one with the potential to form a coalition; within the index utility names are underperforming, which is dragging the utility sector in general down, with some speculation that this may be due to the success of the far right Vox party which secured 24 seats. Downside in utilities likely stemming from pledges by Vox to keep nuclear plants open, which contradicts the incumbent socialist party’s policies of closing nuclear plants and supporting renewable energy, which has been beneficial to Spanish utility names. Notable movers this morning include, Altice (+5.1%) who have reportedly attracted 3 potential bidders for their fibre optic network. Following the dissolution of merger discussions, Commerzbank (+1.6%) have rebutted speculation that the Co. may be sold, stating that they are strong enough alone and their customer relationships remain intact. Elsewhere, Bayer (-2.5%) are down after a spokesman stated that the majority of the Co’s investors voted against ratifying the executive boards 2018 business conduct, for reference the Co. are trading ex-div today.

Anadarko (APC) is said to be preparing to endorse USD 55bln bid from Occidental Petroleum (OXY), according to FT citing sources. (FT) This would jeopardies the Co’s sale to Chevron (CVX)

FX

DXY - The Greenback has regained some composure after last Friday’s post-data downturn, but remains on a mixed footing vs G10 peers and EM currencies at the start of what looks like a busy/pivotal week on paper at least. First up, more inflation data and the Fed’s preferred price measure in the form of core y/y PCE following softer than expected Q1 reads within the advance GDP release, and then it’s month end on Tuesday with FX rebalancing models suggesting a Usd sell signal that could be countered to an extent by supportive SOMA flows. On to May 1, and the FOMC follows the first NFP proxies for Friday via the ADP survey plus employment readings in the manufacturing PMI and ISM. In the run up, the index is straddling 98.000 in a relatively narrow 98.066-97.917 range, with last week’s new 98.330 ytd peak providing resistance vs support at 97.693 that held on Friday.

GBP/EUR/AUD/NZD - Cable continues to display resilience ahead of the 1.2900 handle even though Brexit remains up in the air and talks between the Tory and Labour Party are still grid-locked, but the Pound is still looking toppy around 1.2950 amidst offers at 1.2945 (last month’s low) and with DMAs in close proximity (100 and 200 from 1.2962-65). Similarly, the single currency is finding support off 1.1100 and 2019 lows, as mostly weaker than forecast Eurozone sentiment indicators are countered by a degree of relief post-Spanish election and S&P reaffirming Italy’s BBB rating. Meanwhile, an improvement in Chinese industrial profits and latest US-China trade reports suggesting negotiations are reaching the last stretch are propping up the Aussie and Kiwi circa 0.7050 and 0.6670 respectively.

CHF/CAD/JPY - All on a more even keel vs the Usd and in relatively thin confines as the Franc meanders between 1.0200-1.0185 and Loonie roams from 1.3472-51 amidst a further pull-back in crude and ahead of tomorrow’s Canadian monthly GDP and PPI data. Meanwhile, Usd/Jpy has extended its trading parameters, but only to 111.54-77 in the absence of Japanese markets at the start of Golden Week and with strong chart support sub-111.50 as the 30 DMA, 38.2% Fib retracement of April peak to March trough (112.40-109.70) and last week’s low all fall at 111.37.

EM - At last some respite for the beleaguered Lira as an improvement in Turkish industrial confidence nudges Usd/Try off near 5.9600 peaks awaiting Tuesday’s CBRT inflation report for more independent impetus.

Goldman Sachs sees EUR/USD declining to 1.10 in the next 3 months and DXY rising to 99.00, while it suggested global growth is unlikely to be strong enough to weigh on the greenback. Furthermore, Goldman Sachs forecasts USD/TRY at 6.25 in 3 months, 6.50 in 6 months and 7.00 in 12 months. (Newswires)

FIXED INCOME

Bunds remain around ¼ point underwater at 165.58, but off worst levels as relief gains in Italian debt fade to leave the 10 year Italian benchmark almost flat within a 130.36-95 range. However, Spanish Bonos have advanced a bit further to 151.88 following the weekend election that put PM Sanchez in prime position to begin talks to find partners for a majority regime and this is keeping spreads to core Eurozone paper on a tighter trajectory. Indeed, Gilts and US Treasuries have staged a firmer bounce from worst levels than their German equivalent, with the former up to 127.71 at one stage (-4 ticks vs -26 ticks at the Liffe low) and T-note recovering to 123-22 from 123-18 vs last Friday’s 123-21+ close. Note also, some decent option interest overnight via long bond calls in a diagonal calendar spread.

COMMODITIES

Brent (-0.9%) and WTI (-0.5%) prices are subdued in reaction to US President Trump’s comments on Friday that he contacted OPEC and told them to lower oil prices; although, there were subsequent reports that OPEC or Saudi officials have not spoken to President Trump regarding oil prices. However, some of the downside was mitigated by the Baker Hughes total rig count which fell by 21, with oil rigs falling by 20 to 805 in the steepest decline since January. Regarding the Iranian waivers a Trump Official says there is no wind down period or short-term waiver being considered for China’s oil purchases from Iran, and that it should be easy for China to comply as business with the US is more important for them than Iran. Elsewhere, sources report that exports of Nigeria’s Amenam crude oil is currently under a force majeure; these exports are operated by Total and typically equal 100k BPD.

Gold (-0.3%) is marginally weaker, although the yellow metal is trading within a relatively narrow USD 5/oz range. After the metal printed its biggest daily gain in over a month on Friday, following US data which was disappointing in-spite of the larger than expected headline GDP print of 3.2%. Elsewhere, China’s Iron and Steel association stated that the industry is at risk from excess capacity which could impact profits in the industry.

Eastern Libyan military forces have sent warships to the port of Ras Lanuf, according to a spokesman. (Newswires)

Shell (RDSA LN) has declared force majeure on Nigerian Bonny Light crude exports amid a pipeline closure. (Newswires)

Iraq southern oil exports have averaged 3.33mln BPD in April, according to Oil Officials. In March, southern exports fell to 3.25mln BPD due to bad weather. (Newswires)

Q1 China refined oil demand +0.4% Y/Y to 76.87mln tonnes, according to China State Planner. (Newswires)

Spanish General Election Post-Game: Cataluña becomes the king-maker
content:
As was anticipated, the socialist party PSOE (123) won the Spanish election but fell short of a majority as the PP (66) had its worst turnout in history and VOX gathered 24 seats, marking the first time a far-right party is set to hold seats in the congress of deputies since Francisco Franco. The 123 seats garnered by the incumbent PSOE means that they are now guaranteed to Govern but a viable Government can now only be formed via a coalition. This is possible either with an Unidas Podemos (42) tie-up (requiring the support of regional parties – most likely) or a coalition with Ciudadanos (57) (much less likely as this has been vehemently rejected by Ciudadanos in the past).

Sights will now be set on negotiations with Catalan parties JxCAT (7) and ERC (15) and suggestions of more Catalan regional autonomy will be key. This is because they are now the king-makers of a potential PSOE/Unidas Podemos/Regional Party coalition, and increased autonomy has consistently been a request from both parties.

Whilst political uncertainty remains high until a Government is formed, both MS and Danske expect little immediate impact on financial markets from the largely-in-line results, as the Spanish economy has been “fairly resilient to previous such episodes”, and continued roll-backs on labour-market reforms are “unlikely to inhibit the Spanish growth engine in the short term”. On the medium-term, however, Danske say said reforms may “have negative repercussions on the business environment and public finances in the medium term, with Spain already having one of the highest structural budget deficits in the euro area”.

Bunds: backing off further from Friday’s highs
content: Outperformance at the Eurozone margins appears to be weighing on the 10 year German benchmark and its French counterpart as Italian BTPs breath a sigh of relief after S&P retained its BBB rating, albeit with the outlook still negative, while Bonos are also on a firmer footing following Sunday’s Spanish election saw PM Sanchez secure over 1/3rd of the Parliamentary seats and enough votes to take the lead in terms of forging alliances for a coalition Government. BTP futures have tested resistance just ahead of 131.00 and their 131.12 mtd peak in response with Bonos up to 151.74 and the corresponding yield eyeing 1%. Conversely, Bunds have retreated from 165.84 at best vs their 165.82 previous Eurex settlement to 165.64 with the 10 year yield nudging back up towards parity. Ahead, Eurozone M3 and sentiment indicators along with a speech by de Guindos at some stage.

ASIA

Asian equities traded mixed despite last Friday’s gains on Wall St where sensational Q1 GDP and soft Core PCE Prices suggested a Goldilocks economy and propelled US stock markets to fresh record closes, as this week’s looming risk events and holiday closures restricted upside for the region. ASX 200 (+0.5%) was the laggard amid losses in its largest-weighted financials sector and with energy names also downbeat after a pullback in oil prices, while this week’s array of key releases including Chinese PMI, US NFP, BoE and FOMC announcements also added to the tentative tone. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.9%) was positive after data showed Chinese Industrial Profits recovered in March and with focus on earnings including Agricultural Bank of China which kicked off the Big 4 bank earnings with an improvement in Q1 net, while Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) was less decisive after the PBoC refrained from liquidity operations and with the mainland only open for the first 2 days of this week. As a reminder, Japan is closed until May 7th.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 29th April 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equities traded mixed despite last Friday’s gains on Wall Street, Japanese markets were closed due to the Golden Week Holiday
  • Spain’s election showed that no party won a majority, but the Socialists emerged as the only party with a chance of forming a governing coalition
  • UK Labour is said to be prepared to sign up to a Brexit deal with the government without the promise of a referendum attached if cross-party talks make significant progress in the coming days
  • Looking ahead, highlights include EZ Consumer Confidence & Industrial Sentiment, US Personal Income & Consumption, US PCE Price Index & Dallas Fed and BoE’s Carney
  • Earnings: Alphabet, BBVA, Philips

ASIA-PAC

Asian equities traded mixed despite last Friday’s gains on Wall St where sensational Q1 GDP and soft Core PCE Prices suggested a Goldilocks economy and propelled US stock markets to fresh record closes, as this week’s looming risk events and holiday closures restricted upside for the region. ASX 200 (+0.5%) was the laggard amid losses in its largest-weighted financials sector and with energy names also downbeat after a pullback in oil prices, while this week’s array of key releases including Chinese PMI, US NFP, BoE and FOMC announcements also added to the tentative tone. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.9%) was positive after data showed Chinese Industrial Profits recovered in March and with focus on earnings including Agricultural Bank of China which kicked off the Big 4 bank earnings with an improvement in Q1 net, while Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) was less decisive after the PBoC refrained from liquidity operations and with the mainland only open for the first 2 days of this week. As a reminder, Japan is closed until May 7th.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7310 (Prev. 6.7307)

Chinese Industrial Profits (Mar) Y/Y 13.9% (Prev. -14.0%). (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said trade negotiations with China are in the final laps. (NYT)

UK/EU

UK opposition Labour Party accused the government of refusing to compromise on its red lines in cross-party talks. (Sky News)

Labour is said to be prepared to sign up to a Brexit deal with the government without the promise of a referendum attached if cross-party talks make significant progress in the coming days according to one of the party’s negotiators, while it was separately reported that Labour deputy leader Watson stepped up calls for his party to promise a referendum on any Brexit deal in its European elections manifesto. (Guardian/BBC)

Sources stated that PM May could be axed as PM by the end of June if cross-party talks with Labour break down. (The Sun)

The Conservative party can expect to lose 800 or more seats at this week’s local elections according to a leading Tory analyst. (Guardian)

Spain’s election over the weekend showed no party won a majority but the incumbent Socialists under PM Sanchez emerged as the only party with a chance of forming a governing coalition with 123 out of the 350 seats in parliament, while conservatives won 65 seats, centre right at 57 seats and far fright at 24 seats. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed UK at AA; Outlook Negative and affirmed Netherlands at AAA; Outlook Stable, while S&P affirmed UK at AA; Outlook Negative and affirmed Italy at BBB; Outlook Negative. (Newswires)

FX

In FX markets, the DXY was lacklustre and just about relinquished the 98.00 level following the recent data releases in which a weak PCE inflation number somewhat overshadowed the strong GDP. The greenback’s major counterparts were mildly higher in which EUR/USD prodded above resistance at 1.1150 after the Spanish election results showed incumbent PM Sanchez’s Socialists party won 123 out of the 350 seats in parliament and despite failing to secure a majority, it emerged as the only party with a chance of forming a governing coalition. GBP/USD traded slightly firmer but with upside limited amid conflicting views on cross-party discussions which UK Chancellor Hammond described as productive and suggested optimism on reaching a common ground, while the Labour party accused the government of refusing to compromise on its red lines. Elsewhere, USD/JPY was uneventful amid the 10-day closure in Japan and antipodeans extended on Friday’s mild advances with AUD/USD benefitting as the ruling coalition narrowed the gap against Labor ahead of next month’s election and after the latest ASX 30-Day Interbank Cash Rate futures showed expectations for a rate cut next week slipped to below 50%.

Goldman Sachs sees EUR/USD declining to 1.10 in the next 3 months and DXY rising to 99.00, while it suggested global growth is unlikely to be strong enough to weigh on the greenback. Furthermore, Goldman Sachs forecasts USD/TRY at 6.25 in 3 months, 6.50 in 6 months and 7.00 in 12 months. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were subdued amid the mixed risk sentiment in which WTI crude languished below the USD 63.00/bbl level and with Brent crude closer to the USD 71.00/bbl level to the downside after having rolled over to the July contract during the weekend. The weakness in prices followed the recent pull back from around 6-month highs and after President Trump stated that he had been in touch with OPEC in which he told them to bring oil prices down, although OPEC Secretary General denied speaking to President Trump. Elsewhere, gold traded sideways amid tentativeness ahead of this week’s key releases including the FOMC and copper was also restricted by the indecisiveness in its largest buyer China.

Baker Hughes US Rig Count (26 April 2019): Total rigs -21 at 991 (Prev. 1012), oil rigs -20 at 805 (Prev. 825), gas rigs -1 at 186 (Prev. 187). (Newswires)

US President Trump said he called OPEC and told them to bring oil prices down. In other news, a Trump official said there is no wind down period or short-term waiver being contemplated for China's purchasing of oil from Iran and that it should be easy for China to comply with sanctions as doing business with the US is more important for China than Iran. (Newswires)

Eastern Libyan military forces have sent warships to the port of Ras Lanuf, according to a spokesman. (Newswires)

US

Despite a solid GDP headline, the Treasury complex caught a bid in wake of the Q1 report, with analysts suggesting some of the internals of the report were not as encouraging as the headline. Yields were lower across the curve, and by settlement, the curve had bull steepened. The focus now turns to next week's FOMC, (virtually no chance of a hike - will the Fed acknowledge upward data surprises, and recharacterize its view of the economy? as well as the April Employment Situation Report. US T-note futures (M9) settle 9 ticks higher at123-21+.
